detail.content: Obesity Policy Research | NYU Wagner                                    Jump to navigation                                                             Obesity Policy Research   HPAM-GP.4865, 1.5 points. Semester: Fall       Courses         Description |    Syllabi |    Evaluations           Obesity is a large, pressing public health problem in the United States and, increasingly, across the globe. In contrast to some other public health problems, we have yet to truly establish population-level solutions. Increasingly attention in the policy and research world is being given to policy and environmental approaches to combat obesity, and as such obesity policy is a topic of increasing research. This is a very new field, and much of the research is contradictory, not well interpreted by the media or policy makers, and generally is sparse, relative to some other fields (like smoking policy).    Prerequisites: CORE-GP 1011 and CORE-GP 1018                     Semester     Instructor     Syllabus Link         Fall 2014 Brian Elbel Syllabus                         Semester     Instructor     Evaluation Link         Fall 2014 Brian Elbel Evaluation

The NYU Nutrition and Obesity Policy Research and Evaluation Network (NOPREN) | NYU-CUNY Prevention Research Center                                Skip to main content                      Patient Care       Faculty & Staff Directory       Events       Careers       Donate                                                                                                                                                                             NYU-CUNY Prevention Research Center                                                                                  Home   About Us   Health Promotion Research   Education & Training   Dissemination   News & Events                                  Home Health Promotion Research Special Interest Projects (SIPs) Nutrition and Obesity Policy Research and Evaluation Network (NOPREN)            Print  Email               - A + A                                         Health Promotion Research        open/close   Reaching Immigrants through Community Empowerment (RICE)   Dental Health Promotion Program   Comparative Effectiveness Research (CER)     open/close   Special Interest Projects (SIPs)  Muslim Americans Reaching for Health and Building Alliances (MARHABA)   Nutrition and Obesity Policy Research and Evaluation Network (NOPREN)     Educating Latinos for Better Resources, Outreach, and Nutrition Excellence (EL-BRONX)     open/close   Policy Research   Evaluation                                                                                                    The NYU Nutrition and Obesity Policy Research and Evaluation Network (NOPREN)                                                      The NYU Nutrition and Obesity Policy Research and Evaluation Network (NOPREN) collaborating center is one of six CDC-funded centers across the nation.  It is a multidisciplinary, comprehensive research center that coordinates, develops, and disseminates evidence-based multilevel policy recommendations to address nutrition and obesity prevention for racial and ethnic minorities in urban settings.   NOPREN unites NYU and its community and government partners to conduct research and evaluation projects to inform policy development (Special Interest Project:  2009-2012).  NOPREN partners are preparing a cohesive set of policy recommendations building on existing research on nutrition and obesity prevention in New York City and State. By evaluating existing policies with a focus on racial and ethnic minorities, NOPREN tailors its recommendations to improve the availability and accessibility of healthy food in diverse communities.   2011 Research/Evaluation Efforts   Examining how people make choices at NYC chain restaurants, including how they use posted calorie information to choose healthier foods.   Partnering with the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene on an evaluation project in New York City schools to assess the impact of placing “water jets” (specialized water fountains) in school cafeterias.   Evaluating new NYC nutrition and obesity prevention initiatives.   Partnering with the New York Academy of Medicine to develop and implement ideas on “What Must New York Do Now to Prevent Obesity?”   Read the NOPREN policy brief, "What Must New York Do Now to Prevent Obesity?"   NOPREN Faculty   Brian Elbel, PhD, MPH , (Principal Investigator) NYU School of Medicine and Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service L. A + A                                         Divisions        open/close   Biostatistics  Faculty & Staff   Biostatistics Consulting Center   PhD Program   Upcoming Events       open/close   Epidemiology  Faculty       open/close   Healthcare Delivery Science     open/close   Medical Ethics  Masters Program   Training Opportunities   News & Publications   Events Listing   Faculty   Volunteer for Research   Donate   External Links, Blogs, and Other Resources   NYU Medical Ethics Resources   NYU Working Group on Compassionate Use       open/close   Health and Behavior  News   Faculty   Staff   Research   Center for Healthful Behavior Change (CHBC)   Center for Stroke Disparities Solutions (CSDS)   Section on Health Choice, Policy and Evaluation (HCPE)   Section on Tobacco, Alcohol, and Drug Use (TADU)   Section for Health Equity   Center for Early Childhood Health and Development (CEHD)   Community Service Plan       open/close   Comparative Effectiveness and Decision Science  Section on Value and Effectiveness (SOLVE)   Section on Tobacco, Alcohol, and Drug Use (TADU)   Section on Health Choice, Policy and Evaluation (HCPE)   Current Research   Divisional Faculty   Divisional Staff   News       open/close   Sections and Other Programs  Section on Health Choice, Policy and Evaluation  Faculty & Staff   Contact   Research Nutrition and Obesity Research and Evaluation Network (NOPREN)   Publications     Events   News     Section on Tobacco, Alcohol, and Drug Use (TADU)                                                                        Nutrition and Obesity Research and Evaluation Network (NOPREN)                                               The NYU Nutrition and Obesity Policy Research and Evaluation Network (NOPREN) collaborating center is one of five CDC-funded centers across the nation. NOPREN is a multidisciplinary, comprehensive research center that coordinates, develops, and disseminates evidence-based multilevel policy recommendations to address nutrition and obesity prevention for racial and ethnic minorities in urban settings.      NOPREN unites NYU and its community and government partners to conduct research and evaluation projects to inform policy development. NOPREN partners are preparing a cohesive set of policy recommendations building on existing research on nutrition and obesity prevention in New York City and State. By evaluating existing policies with a focus on racial and ethnic minorities, NOPREN tailors its recommendations to improve the availability and accessibility of healthy food in diverse communities.      NOPREN is led by Dr. Brian Elbel and Courtney Abrams, in conjunction with academic partners at the NYU School of Medicine, College of Nursing, Steinhardt School of Culture, Education and Human Development, and the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service.                     Evaluation of a Large-Scale Drinking Water Availability Intervention in NYC Schools      New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH) is conducting a large-scale intervention to increase drinking water availability in elementary, middle and high schools. They are installing and promoting “water jets” which provide free, cool, filtered NYC tap water to students in the cafeteria. Schools were recruited to participate in this study, including elementary schools, middle schools, and high schools. Half of the schools received a water jet and half did not. Data were collected through direct observation of cafeterias, student surveys, and staff interviews, before and after water jets were installed in participating schools. Factors measured include implementation processes, utilization of installed water dispensers, student water consumption, student perceptions of drinking water, and student consumption of other beverages such as sugary drinks and milk both during and outside of school hours. This project is a collaborative evaluation conducted by DOHMH and New York University School of Medicine, with technical support and guidance provided by content experts from CDC’s Division of Nutrition, Physical Activity, and Obesity. Funded by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention under cooperative agreement number 1-U48-DP-001904-01.         Role of Calorie Labeling in Food and Restaurant Choices      Calorie labeling on fast food restaurant menus has shown limited effectiveness on altering food choices, particularly among racial and ethnic minorities residing in low-income communities. Reasons for why this policy has not been successful among these populations must be explored. We are examining the factors behind food choices and how they relate to calorie labeling by assessing the following:       Structural reasons: noticing, understanding of, and ability to fully utilize calorie labels as currently presented       Decision-making factors: the role that calorie information plays in the customers’ food choices.      We are conducting focus group meetings and key informant interviews. In addition to exploring the influence of calorie labeling on food choices, we collect information on background factors, such as education level and risk for obesity. Lastly, we utilize the focus group results to provide greater insight into the potential effectiveness of policies meant to combat obesity. The information is being collected in four boroughs in New York City: the Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan, and Queens. Funded by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention under cooperative agreement number 1-U48-DP-001904-01.         NYC Adopt-A-Bodega Evaluation      In low-income, predominantly minority areas of NYC, small corner stores (known as bodegas) are often the most prevalent local source of food, but often offer less variety of fresh fruits and vegetables than larger food venues. The goal of this study is to evaluate the effect of a nutritional and community advocacy training intervention on purchases made in select bodegas located near elementary schools in the South Bronx. We have partnered with a community organization, Bronx Health REACH (BHR), which has conducted series of nutrition education programs for parents of students in elementary schools. They then implemented an "Adopt a Bodega" program modeled after the NYC DOHMH program under the same name, and provided parents with the tools to make corner stores located close to the schools healthier. Parents at the schools receive training to make sustainable changes within bodegas; we analyze the results at these and additional school-bodega pairs which act as control sites. We are particularly interested in seeing if the changes that result from the Adopt a Bodega advocacy training has an impact on food purchases made by the general public. Street-intercept surveys are administered to consumers before and after the intervention to examine the impact, if any, that the intervention had on foods purchased in the selected corner stores. Funded by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention under cooperative agreement number 1-U48-DP-001904-01.
